* This province is massive in space, but has a very small population because it is an arid desert: این تومان بغایت وسیع و کثیر الاراض میباشد و قلیل النفوس است اراضی بایر غیر مزروع
* Despite the poverty of the soil, the province is exclusively made up of farmers... they are just poor farmers.
9
* Also, only about one in a hundred people are literate in this province.
* Mazar: مزار فایض الانوار سید احمد which is famous for the "11 Ahmads", 9 of which are located in other villages.
9b
* This province was ravaged during wars with Khiva, which is another reason the province is depopulated.
* Only about a fourth of the province remains; the rest to the north and west has been swallowed by sand.
* The aforementioned mazar is to the son of Uthman: مزار فایض الانوار حضرت ابان بن عثمان بن عفان
10
* Province is situated on the northwest side of Bukhara.
* The province has another name used only in official documents: ختفر
* The province (قصبه تومان) of __سامجن__ which is better known as رامتین. 
* This province has a large population but little farming.
* Entirely a farming community.
* There is a very old ruin in this province attributed to the daughter (دخت) of افراسیاب
10b
* The province name رامتین comes from آرام تن from when Afrosiab's daughter was sick and became well again in that locale.
* Naqshbandi mazar: مزار فایض الانوار بابای سماسس که رشد حضرت شاه نقشبند 
* The author credits the courts (محکمه) for the prosperity int his province because it is known for its unruliness: در نهایت درجۀ شورش و غوغا اند
11
* Author includes a story about why the province is so unruly: When Adam and Eve and the serpent were cast out of heaven, the devil landed in Ramitin.
* Sand is also overtaking this province.
* Most of the residents are poor.
* The قصبه تومان of __خیرآباد__ is the smallest of Bukhara's provinces.
11b
* The reason Khairabad is so small is because half of it has been enveloped by sand.
* Before it was swallowed by the sand, Paikand used to be connected to this province as well as قراکول.
12
* Among the old buildings of this province is the قورغان named تاراب.
* Ruins such as that of an ark reveal that there was once a grand city in this area.
* The inhabitants of this area were also subject to a siege by the Khivans and fled to the local Qurghan.
* Inhabitants are almost exclusively farmers.
* The قبصه تومان of __وردانزه__ better known as شافرکام.
* This is also a small province as a third of it was swallowed in the past century to the north and west.
12b (//author's page 24//)
* Mazar: فایض الانوار حضرت سید اتأ
** //what is the deal with all of these mazaars starting with// فایض الانوار? //must be a title//
** This mazar was celebrated in prose by میرزا صفر منشی منجمین متخلص عبدی; author repeats the verses on this page.
* Mazar: مزار فایض الانوار حضرت خواجه عارف ماه تایان
* This province is fairly wealthy and is made up of traders; also a large population of Kazakhs.
13
* These aforementioned Kazakhs are nomadic and herders.  They are of the کوکچی and آقا اتأ tribes.
* The قصبه تومان of __وَغانزه__ (//Faizollah says this is an old Soghdian word//) which is better known کام ابو مسلم or گام ابو مسلم
* This province is largely made up of Arabs of Qutaiba's armies of the Najib tribe as well as Uzbeks.
* It is a well-off province with a renowned Bazaar.
13b
* Home to a nice Khanaqa built in 1280.
* Large population.
* Since the province is connected to a plain (چول ملک) many people here own horses and animals.
* The Russian railroad extends into this province.

14
* Inhabitants are entirely farmers; they are generally wealthy and the province is filled with gardens.
* The railroad is connected to the eastern end of this province; the station is called قزیل تپه.
* 5 farsakhs from Bukhara; it is connected by the old road of میانکال.
* Mazar: حضرت عبد الواسع
* People here are good natured and like music and conviviality (ساز و طرب).
* There are also a number of Hindu Magians (هنود مجوس) living in the province who work as moneylenders: و مقدار سیصد نفو از هنود مجوس در اینجا ساکن و ربواخواری مشغولند
14b
* Province has excellent Arabian horses.
* The Zarafshan (دریای زرافشان) river is located to the southwest of the province.

!!!Chapter 2: MianKol - مقاله دویم در ذکر ایالت واسعۀ میانکال
14b
* Origin of the name: Historians offer several explanations.  Some say it is minspronunciation of "میان دو کوه".
* The province is situated between two mountain ranges - نور اتأ  to the north and the متصلا mountain range to the south.
* The seat of government is Karmina: مرکز حکومت این ایالت ولایت کرمینه میباشد
* The province is broken into eight subgovernments (حکومت) which are: : کرمینه، ضیأ الدین، حضرت جی، باغچه کلان، نور اتآ، غجوم سرای، کان میغ، نیک قورغان
15
* The ولایت of __کرمینه__:
* This province is also home to ruins from Afrosiab in the south near the Zarafshan river.
* More insane sycophancy: جناب امیر المومنین و امام المسمین سید امیر عبد الاحد خان - //the "kitchen sink" approach to titles//
* During the "Caliphate" (خلافت) of Abd al-Ahad's father, Abd al-Ahad ruled this province and he built a palace there.  This palace was built in 1290 and was of unparalleled grandeur.
15b
* The province is extremely populous and also has a lot of fruit and water.
* Province is made up almost exclusively of Uzbeks, but there are also Najib Arabs.  In a village there are also about 200 Iranians.  In the Qurghan there are some Hindu Magians, as well as some wealthy Jews.
16
* About 50,000 households in the province.
* Mazar: فایض الانوار حضرت قاسم شیخ
16b
* آنف البیان is the name of a famous sarai in the region and it is owned by one of the leading Qaravol (قراول) houses of Bukhara.
* Population is mostly made up of itnerant Uzbeks.
* This area also has some ancient ruins.
* There is a grave of a moneylender (سودخوار) near the mazar of مزار حضرت قاسم شیخ
17
* Above the aforementioned mazar is a stone with pictures of snakes and scorpions; no matter how hard people try to rub them off, they remain.
* The village of قرنب is located 5 farsakhs away. It is entirely mountainous.  It is entirely Uzbek.
** Two main groups (فرقه) of Uzbeks: اکیت و درگر یربُزبله (sp.?); also the اوج اوراغ
17b
* There is excellent hunting in this province, including gazelles. 
* In addition to hunting there are sheepherders and camelherders in this province.
* Between کرمینه و قرنب is a famous cave at the mountain کوه چادر تپه. The cave is known as بابا اتأ and people put a rope down it every year and go into it to tell stories.  The author himself visited the cave to inquire about it.
* Here the author references a book published in Istanbul.
18 
* This aforementioned Turkish book says that the aforementioned cave connects to Yemen: (continuing from previous page) نقل مینماید که از جوف زمین بخارای شریف در ولایت یمن که از اقلیم افریقا است راه اسد
* Page goes on about the value of some very excellent water that comes from a spring.
18b
* قَرنَب is located 11 farsakhs to the east of Bukhara.
* It's inhabitants consider themselves to be sayyids: اهلی قرنب خودهایشانرا از احفاد اهل بیت بنس میدانستند
* Likewise, the name of the province comes from قریب بنی
* سرمیج is another village with a spring in this province.
* All of the next page is devoted to describing the magnificent gardens of Sarmich which, according to the author, are a wonder of the earth.
19
* Composed of 200 households, mostly Uzbek.
* The amir has a Chaharbogh in this village.
* There is also a remarkable mulberry (توت) tree there that grows directly out of the rock: از جوف سنگ بر آمده است تحت ساق آن قطعا خاک ندارد
* The nearby village of دادش has a spring.
19b
* Said village is also host to a community of خواجه گان, i.e. of Arab descent.
* The next قضا is __ینگی قورغان__, which is composed of two separate parts, the second of which is called هزاره.
* Like everywhere else, there are ancient ruins in this village.
* It is a populous province with 7,000 families, 3,000 of which are Uzbek, 4,000 Arab.
20
* Mazar: مزار فایض الانوار مولانا عارف 
* هزاره is composed of 3,000 households, entirely Uzbek.
* This village is apparently also famous for its Arabian horses.
20b
* The second government (حکومت) of MianKal (the first of which was کرمینه) is __ضیأ الدین__
** Note that [[Hisari worked here|Muhammad Ḥisari, Yāddāshthā, 1268-1296]] for a while.
* Also known as: نهر پَی and قلعه دبوس.
* It is the widest (وسیع ترین) province of MinaKal at 18 farsakhs.
* Inhabitants are largely Uzbek; one is the نیمن tribe and the other خطای
* About two thirds of the province are urben dwellers (اهل تمدن); the rest are pastoralists.
* They are known for their exceptional horses, which are sold in Bukhara.
21
* The province is extremely fertile and the peasants do just fine as farmers.  Also has lots of marvelous water springs coming from the surrounding mountains.
* 70,000 residents total.
* A railroad connects to the southern side of this province.
* Every year 2/3 (ثلثان) of the produce of this province is sent to Bukhara (possibly by rail, though the author does not explicitly say so.
21b
* @@Many Ulama originate from this province@@: این مملکت مسقط الرأس بسیار از علمأ و فقهأ و فضلأ و شعرأ بوده
** Every year during the scholarly season (در ایام تحصیل) more than a thousand students go from here to Bukhara for schooling.
* Located 18 farsakhs from Bukhara to the east.
* In the location of توغی رباط there is a cotton factory (زود پخته - from the Russian zavod).
** Author notes that the cotton factory was built by the government of Bukhara: از طرف دولت بخارا بنا شده است
** The factory is of unparalleled volume such that: در پاریژ و برلین و لندن و مسکو نیست
*** //interesting that author is stacking the state of Bukhara against these competing Western powers//
* The third حکومت of MianKal of __خطیر چی__
* A populous province of soldiers and merchants second in quantity only to Bukhara.
22
* The province is bounded on the north by a mountain range and to the south by the Zerafshan river.
* Province is home to a population of Hindu Magian moneylenders and some Jews up to the same.  However, Uzbeks are the most populous group in this province.
* The province also has a bit of a gambling problem.  In general the province is given to vice:  فعل منکر میسر درین بلده بسیار شیوع دارد و جوان خورد و کلان آنها باین بلیۀ مبتلا اند
22b
* Mud is a seriously problem in this province during the winter and every year a few horses are left to die at the pass.
* Total households: 35,000.
* 18 farsakhs from the eastern corner of Bukhara.  Adjoins the eastern side of کرمینه, which is 5 farsakhs away.
* (marginalia) a marvel of this province is a quivering rock (سنگ جنبان)
23
* The حکومت of __باغچه کلان__
* Even though this province is connected to Karmina (این مملکت هر چند که حاکم برأسه دارد ضمیمه حکومت ولایت کرمینه است), people go to Khatarchi to resolve disputes: لیکن من حیث المرافعه کانه از ملحقات ولایت خطیر چی
** Reason: the north of this province is entirely mountainous, so the citizens cannot go that way for justice.
* Gardens of Iram reference: این ولایت بدرون کوه بلب چشمه آب ها است خصوصا موضع کوک سرای که گوی سبقت از باغ ارم ربوده است
* Entire province is made up of Uzbek tribes.
* 7,000 households.
* 18 farsakhs to Bukhara.
* Population is entirely agrarian.
23b
* The حکومت of __کان میخ__
* Province has a formidable Qurghan on the top of a hill situated between two plains (قیر), one named خزلان and the other پای دلدل and they extend to بابا دوغی
* این قسبه از محاذی قورغان ولایت کرمینه انتهای آن ممتد تا توقوز تپه میشود
* This province is actually mostly made up of Karakalpaks قره قلپاق, as well as some قزاق و اندک قبیله اوزبک
** The karakalpaks there are sedentary (متمدن); the Kazakhs are nomadic.
* There are even some Khirgiz قیرغز
24
* Nearby location: توقوز, where people like to hunt and farm.
* 9,000 households; 11 farsakhs from Bukhara from Bukhara's northeast corner, 3 from Karmina.
* The حکومت و ولایت of __نور اتاء__
24b
* Qurghan of this province is located atop a mighty mountain.
** This Qurghan is also notable for its connections to Alexander the Great: قورغان یلایت مذکوره از ضمله اثار ملک اسکندر ذو القرنین است
*** بجانب جنوبی این قورغان مقدار نیم فرسخ قدم گاه ملک اسکندر نیز موجود است مشهور به ذو القرنین است الحال زیارت گاه انام است
25
* There is a sequestering house (چله خانه) where Bahauldin Naqshband used to frequent. Now it is a meeting place of the Sufi pillars of the age: پنج شب سر این چشمه خالی از مردمان پوشیده حال و اهل الله نیست محل اجماع چهل تن و قطب و اوتاد است
* Population: 16,000 families.  Mostly merchants and knitters by profession, some farmers.  Generally a wealthy population.
* Mazar in surrounding village: شیخ احمد کبیر
25b
* Footprints of Ali in the outskirts of Nurata: غزغان است در آنجا قدم گاه امیر المومنین حضرت علی یار چهارم
* There is also a sacred footprint spot of قدم گاه بابا قنیر above which there is the image of a camel.
* Nearby there is yet another footprint area of Hussain and Hasan (امامین).
* To the north we have another Qadamgah, this time of Imam Hanifa.
* There is also a marble quarry in the area (معدن سنگ مرمر) as well as one for lime plaster: پیشه و حرفه آنها سنگ تراش است معدن سنگ مرمر آنجا است و معدن آهک نیز در اینجا موجود است
26
* Every year 10,000 camels of آهک are exported from this mine.
* The people there are known for the trays they make from the marble.
* Other nearby villages: فَنِکَت - فنکت غُجومسرای - عجومسرای
* Residents are primarily Tajikis with some Najib Arabs
26b
* There are also many Turkmen in the vicinities of this province.
* The inhabitants of this region have developed a special kind of subterranean canal: و چشمه آبهای مصنوعی که باصطلاح اهالی کوهستان آنرا کاریز میگویند
** In the past this province had 360 of these کاریز; now there are only 100.
** //evidence of deteriorating irrigation//
* Population home to 10,000 households of قزاق و قره قلپاق و کربیت
* Coal working: کسب آنها بیستر انگشت سوزی و انگشت فروشی است
* Province is surrounded by massive mountains.
27
* 18 farsakhs from Bukhara from the northeast corner of Bukhara.
* Province is 15 farsakhs long; connected to جزخ on one side.
* The northern mountains are well-suited to hunting foxes and سوسار, //whatever that is (Faizollah says something like a hyena).//
* The __total population__ of میانکال is 210,000 households which amounts to about half a million individuals.

!!!Chapter 3: Labi Ab لب آب
27b
* This is a long thin province - east to west it is 50 farsakhs.
* It also separates Bukhara from Afghanistan and touches Khiva.
* The province is almost entirely made up of Turkmen. They are the bravest and most fervent of all Central Asia: که غیور و جسور ترین قبایل و عشایر اهالی و رعایایی ما ورأ النهر
* On the importance of the Amu Darya: اکثر ایالتهای بخارا بکنار این نهر است  ازین سبب منبع و مصب این نهر را بیان نمودن خالی از منفعت نیست.  
** Also discusses the source of the Amu Darya in the Pamirs: بام دنیا مینامند ابتدای آمویه
28
** The Amu Darya flows all the way to the Aral Sea (کول ارل) which is between Astrakhan and Khiva: که در میانه خیوه و هشتر خان است
* Mentions Kirkih کرکه, which is today in Turkmenistan and called Ata Murod, named after Niyazov's father.
* This province (ایالت) is divided into into 11 (قضاء) districts.
[[Manuscripts Index]]
[[Semenov, ed., Sobranie Vostochnykh Rukopisei Akademii Nauk Uzbekskoi SSR]]

General Comments
* Folios Tārīkh-i Khumūlī (al-Biruni 37) 133b-183b are identical to: [[Tarjuma-i Ḥāl-i Qāẓī Jumʿa-Qul Khamūlī]]
* Full length: 133b-345b; Sections V and / or VI (SVR lists VI, V actually listed on p. 133b)
* Discussed extensively in Anke von Kügelgen, Legitimatsiia sredneaziatskoi dinastii mangitov d proizvedeniiakh ikh istorikov, XVIII-XIX vv. (Almaty: Daik-Press, 2004).
** Text not written all at once: "Листы 138а-280а, в которых он описывает свое образование и правление мангитов, были написаны, очевидно, в 1252/1836-37 г. и 1253/1837-38 г. Между тем последние пятьдесят шесть листов (280а-345а) были написаны позже" (214).
** pages 208a-281b are about Muhammad and the rightly guided caliphs (164).
* Another independent historian is Ḵomuli (b. 1776-77, d. after 1847) who served as the judge (qāżi) of Urgut near Samarqand. He left an untitled work which today is known as Tāriḵ-e Ḵomuli (von Kügelgen, 2002a, esp. pp. 157-67), but the work was not much cited during Ḵomuli’s lifetime. The text begins with a lengthy account of how he, the son of a herdsman, overcame many obstacles to obtain a comprehensive education in the esoteric and exoteric sciences (al-ʿolum al-ẓāhira wa’l-ʿolum al-bāṭina). Ḵomuli’s intellectual autobiography is followed by the biographies of his teachers and of other Sufi sheikhs who belonged to the Naqšbandiya-Mojaddediya branch of Dahbed near Samarqand. The work includes a section dedicated to the Manḡïts, with many rare details about Šāh Morād whom Ḵomuli greatly admired. But Ḵomuli is an exception among Transoxanian historians because he discusses how in 1743 Nāder Shah Afšār attempted to end the Shiʿite-Sunnite hostilities in Najaf. Ḵomuli idealistically judged Nāder Shah’s political move as an effort to implement an agreement, according to which Shiʿites and Sunnites would cease to consider each other infidels and which would thus end sectarian violence, warfare, and bloodshed (Ḵomuli, fols. 187a-188b). From: Kungelen, BUKHARA viii. Historiography of the Khanate, 1500-1920, Encyclopedia Iranica.


!!!Historical Section (183b-
Introduction
* Opening line relating Manghit dynasty to sacred history (183b): بیان ثنا - ثنا قادریرا که بر گزیده بمنصب جهان بانی از آل یافث قبیلۀ اوزبک راه خاتیار نمود و از شعوب اوزبک شعبۀ منغت را چنانچه خواست [بوجی] رسانی پیغمبری از نسل سام
** Poem comparing Manghits to Quraysh (183b): قریش است مقصد ز احفاد سام - ز اوزبک باولاد یافث نظام - بنو هاشم آمد ضیای قریش - چه منغت ز اوزبک بجای قریش

Nadir Shah (187-189b): تتمۀ وقایع نادر شاه چون حادثه نادری بمنزلۀ مقدمه است مر دولت خواقین منغتیه را بتقریب اولاً باید که قصۀ نادر شاه را بیان نمایم
* Opening line on Nadir Shah's religious goals (187): صورت واقعه این بود که نادر شاه بعد از فتح بلاد ایران و توران و هندوستان خواست که تحقیق مذاهب حقه بر وچه حق نه از روی تعصب نموده بکدام مذهبی که از روی برهان بصواب مقرون باشد اتباع نماید 
* (cont.) Bringing Sunnis and Shias together (i.e. convincing the Shiites to renounce their heresy) (187): بنابرین علمأ اهل سنت و جماعت و علماء اهل تشیع و سایر قلّت را از ماوراءالنهر و ایران و هندوستان احضار فرموده بصحرای موقان که از توابع [مادغس] ست  اجلاس فرموده علما را گفت که پی شایبۀ تکلف و خایلۀ تعسّف  رجوع بکتاب و سنّت و آثال سلف و اخبار خلف نموده درین باب بذل جهد و سعی را بجای آورده مداهب حقه را از ملل باطله امتیاز [دانند
* (cont.) Hadi Khwajah's participation, conclusions of the council (187-187b): دران مجمع از علمای بخارا جناب استاد الاستاد ایشان هادی خواجه علامه العصر مولوی میرزا امید و غیرهما از فحول علما حاضر بوند بعد از مباحثه و مناظره اجماع نمودند که اگر شیعه رفض و سب کبار صحابه رضوان الله تعالی عنهم اجمعین نه نماید در اصول و فروع از تقلید امام الانس و الجن اعز حضرت امام جعفر صادق رضی الله عنه و عن ائایه العظام چنانچه دعوی دارند نبرایند مذهب ایشان مذهب خامس باشد از مذاهب اربعه حق و من بعد هیچکدام از اهل سنت و تشیع یکدیگر را تکفیر نکنند و قتل و بیع و تاراج همدیگر را تجویز ننمایند و تعصب و طرف گیری را حرام دانسته بیوجه صریح تکفیر اهل قبله نسازند چون در فروغ مذهب شیعه بمذهب امام شافعی و مالک رحمهما الله متقارب ست در کعبه و بیت الله زادها الله تعالی شرفاً و عزاً در یلی یکی ازین دو فرقه از ارکان [اربع؟] خانه نماز گذارند کسی ایشانرا منع ننماید
** (cont.) signing an agreement to this effect (187b-188): علما صورت اجماع را در صحفه وسیعه نوشته مجموع اکابر اسلام از طرفین مُهرهای خود را در ان صحیفه ثبت نمودند شاه مذکور بجماعۀ علما انعام و احسان بروجه اتم نموده فرمود که خدای تعالی سعی شما را ضایع ننموده مشکور و مقبول [گردان] و علی الخصوص بعلماء سنیه از استادین و غیرهما مراحم بسیار و عواطف بیشمار بجای آورده اعزاز و احترام ایشانرا از دیگران زیاده تر نمود
* (cont.) Involving the Ottomans in the reform (188): بعد از ان صورت اجماع علما را بر وجه که گذشت نوشته بخدمت خلیفۀ روم که سواد اعظم اسلام است مصحوب رسولان [و اتا] فرستاده التماس قبول و تقاضای اتفاق باجماع علمای ایران و توران ننموده فرمود که از امت رسول عالمیان پیغمبر اخر الزمان مهما امکان تکفیر یکدیگر نمودن و تجویز بیع و قتل و محابره داشتن بسیار نازیبا ست درین آوان بتوفق ملک منّان امید داریم که مبادی وحشت و اسباب [مبانیست] از میان سنّی و شیعه بر طرف گردیده مادۀ نزاع طرفین بالکل بر طرف گردد
** Ottoman response (188b): اجماع علما را اضظا فرمایند چون رسولان داخل روم گردیدند بعد از گذارش سفارت و ادای رسالت جناب خلافت پنهای فرمان واجب [الاوغان؟] باحضار علماء روم و اکابر آن مرزبوم ارزانی نموده فرمودند چه میگونید درجواب شاه ایران علمأ آن دیار از قبول این معنی ابا و امتناع نموده رسولان شاه بی نَیلِ مدعا بدربار شاهی مراجعت نمود
* Nadir's Qizilbash become suspicious that he is a closet Sunni and murder him for it (189): در ان اثنا اکابر شیعیه و امراء قزیلباشیه که از شاه مذکور تفرس تسنّن نموده متوهم بودند که او توقیر و تعظیم علمأ سنّی را بیش از علمأ شیعه نموده مبادا که که اختیار مذهب اهل سنت نموده مذهب شیعه را ترک و شیعه را مستأصل گرداند فرصت را غیمت دانسته چون لشکر اوزبکیه و افغانیه اکثری در ان لشکر حاضر نبودند منصب ندیمی و حراست بقزیلباشیه متعین بود ندیمان و محرمان شاه را بااین آوردند که شب در فراش خواب او را قتل نمایند و آن بیسعادتان بعضی بطوع و برخی بکره و جمعی از راه تعصب شیع بر بالای شاه هجوم آورده اورا بقتل آوردند و پگاه آن شکریه یکدیگر اغارت نموده هر کس بدیار خود باز  یکباره گرفتی 
* Khumuli summing up his thoughts on Nadir Shah (189b): موّز خان؟] اتفاق دارند که از زمان امیر تیمور گورگان انار الله برهان تا این وقت که سنه 1252 است پادشاه جهان گیری از اهل اسلام و کفر چون نادر شاه باورنگ جهان بانی نه نشسته قواعد فریدون را یاسیاست چنگیزی و شجاعت تیموری جمع آورده بود صورتی داشت درغیات زیبای و سیرتی داشت در نهایت دانایی اینست ختم کار نادر شاه بر سبیل اجمال

Rahim Khan and the end of Abu al-Fayz (189b-): بیان سلطنت محمد رحیم خان که اول سلاطین منغتیه است
* Opening - Rahim Khan left in charge of the Uzbek tribes (189b): اکنون مگا ان قلم از میدان قصه شاه معطوف داشته بسر داستان جلوس سعادت مأنوس محمد رحیم خان بعنایت ملک منان بر سریر مملکت بخارا و ترکستان باید آمدن چون بفرمان و یارلیغ هر چنانچه گذشت محمد رحیم خان عازم ماورأ النهر گردیده و بقیه لشکر اوزبکیه که در پس شاه بودند باو ملحق گردیدند
* (cont.) Upon hearing of the murder of Nadir Shah, Rahim orders that the news be kept secret and begins to march on Bukhara (189b-190): و قتل شاه بی اشتباه معلوم گردید محمد رحیم خان برفقایئ دلیل اقبال در لشکر فرمود که واقعه قتل نادر شاه را در دلها پنهان داشته [زینها = زنهار] ازینمقوله احدی لب نکشید که زبانرا از دهن و سر را از بدن خواهد بار داد و راه ها را احتیاط نمود که کسی از تجار و غیر آن این خبر را پیش نبرد چون ایزد تعالی خواسته بود که در عالم انقلاب دولت از خاندان چنگزیه بدودمان منغیته واقع گردد این تدبیر موافق تقدیر آمده قتل شاه را هیچ احدی به بخارا و ماوراالنهر نآورد تا که خان و اتباع آن از دریای جیحون عبور نموده 
* (cont.) Abu al-Fayz (190): (section on Abu al-Fayz I don't quite understand)
* The Shia commanders wish to avenge Nadir Shah (190b): شیعه قاصد درگاه شاهی گردیده بسوی مقصود [راهی] شدند چون خان از شهر بخارا بر امد و امرا نزدیک شهر گردیدند خبر قتل شاه مشهور گردید سرداران شیعه بخان عرضه نوشتند که ما همه غلام و بنده ایم باید که بلشکر ما تشریف قدوم ارزانی دارند که باز بضرب شمشیر خانرا بتخت خورثی نشانده انتقام از اعادی خواهیم کشید
* The general chaos under Abu al-Fayz was so great that Nadir Shah was welcomed (192): ایالات از وی نفور نموده اینمعنی علاوۀ ضعف و بعاث دهن او رگدید از بخارا مطلاقا بیرون نآمده درین اثنا عباد الله خطای از میان کال خروج کرده  چند رفعه ببالای بخارا لشکر برده تاراج و غارت را بافراط رسانید انچنین در تمام ماوراالنهر ظلم و بیداد او عام شد سرداران قبایل دیگر تاب مقاومت و طاقت محاربت او نداشتند تا در اخیر خان شهید استغاثه شاه ایران برده  کار او را بانجام رسانید
* Khumuli explains the necessity of keeping a Chingissid on the throne and that Rahim took the position of Ataliq.  Then Rahim's relation to Nadir's power and incorporating Nadir's military rules (192b-193): رسوم و آداب سلطنت و جهانداری را از نادر شاه آموخته بود قواعد پسندیده در ملک نصب نمود و نظام عسکریه که از [بی پروایی] خان شهید بر هم خورده بود از سر تازگی یافت
* Hisar and the Yuz rebellion (193): اکثر امرأ قبایل اوزبک منقاد او گردیدند غیر از محمد امین بی مینگ ورد قربان اتالیق یوز که از بخارا باحتراز بر امده بحصار رفته اغاز طغیان و اظهار عصیان نمود
** //I think he subdues the rebellion, but don't fully understand the rest of this page//
* After securing Bukhara, Rahim Khan conquers the rest of Mawarannahr, but not without a fight.  Rahim Khan wins the battle, but he does not take those cities or remove the governors from power (193b-194): از تنظم امور بخارا و تومنات آن فارغ گردیده به تسخیر ممالک دیگر عَلَبِ جهان گیری را بر افراخت و در اندک مدّتی خطه ماورانهر  را در حیطه تسخیر در اورده میان کالات و سمرقند بتوابع و لو احق آن مفتوح گشت و حاکم نوراتا طغایمراد بی بر قوت در اول عصیان ورزیده بعد از محاربات و مصافات بسیار مطیع و منقاد گردیده در زمرۀ امراء عظام منتظم گردید حصار محمد امین بی یوز و حاکم شهر سبز سبحانقلی بی کنیگس و حاکم خجند و اوراتپبه فاضل بی یوز و حاکم اورگوت موسی بی مینگ باتفاق همدیگر بخان مذکور یاغی گردیده میان ایشان و خان عالی شان محاربات شدیده بدفعات رویداد در تمام آن معارک ظفر در جانب خالی بود و لشکر ظفر اثر بالای شهرسبز برده بضرم شمشیر آمد از سرسر داران آن بقعه را بخاک مذلت و بوار فرود آورد بعد از قتل و قال بسیار و حرب و جدال بی شمار آن مملکت بهار خاصیت را از ان جماعه استخلاص نمود و مرارا لشکر ها بحصار و ارواتپه و خجند فرستاده حکام آن دیار را ضعیف و زیون گردانید
* Describing the battle of four armies (see also [[Hakim Khan|Muḥammad Ḥakīm Khān, Muntakhab al-Tavārīkh 1842: Rahim Khan through Shah Murad]]) - Uratipa and Hisar on one side, Bukhara and Khoqand on the other - using Shahnamah terminology (194b-195): دران روز جنگ سخت و محاربه قوی در میان فرقه اربعه رویداد که آسمان با صد هزار چشم کواکب مثل این واعه را در خواب ندیده و بهرام باین تیغ خون آشام صورت اینمحاربه را بگوش خیال نشنیده

Danial Bay (201-

Shah Murad (213-

Timur Shah and Balkh (239-

Amir Haydar (265-

(Shahrisabz letter - 279b)




[[Travel Literature Index]]

> Armenius Vambery, Travels in Central Asia; Being the Account of a Journey from Teheran Across the Turkoman Desert on the Eastern Shore of the Caspian to Khiva, Bokhara, and Samarcand (New York: Harper & Brothers, 1865).

See also E. Shuiler" / Schuyler, "Na skol'ko dostoverny razskazy Vambery o Srelnei Azii (Turk. Sbornik T. 81, p. 437; Znanie, 1873, No. 10).  There is actually tons of debate  over the veracity of Vambery's journey - see Turkestanskii Sbornik Ukazatel' 1 starting on p. 19.

About the author and his quest:
* Born in Hungary in 1832; became interested in Oriental languages - i.e. trying to figure out what branch Hungarian belonged to (vii).
* Spent several years in Istanbul, then decided to travel to Central Asia disguised as an effendi (viii).
* "My attention was for the most part directed to the races inhabiting Central Asia, of whose social and political relations, character, usages, and customs I have striven, however, imperfectly, to giver a sketch in the following pages" (viii).
* High adventure: "... I wandered about for months and months with only a few rags as my covering, without necessary food, and in constant peril of perishing by a death of cruelty, if not of torture" (xiii).

Getting ready to depart
* Turkey vs. Iran: "... Iran, the theme of so much poetic enthusiasm, is, after all, nothing but a frightful waste, whereas Turkey is really an earthly paradise" (23).
** "The Persian can boast a poetic organization and an ancient civilization.  The superiority of the Osmanli results from the attention he is paying to the langauges of Europe, and his disposition gradually to acquaint himself with the progress that European savans have made in chemistry, physics, and history" (23).
* Dost Muhammad was laying siege to Herat, where Vambery was heading: "Persians themselves dared not venture their wares or their lives; but there would have been far more cause for apprehension in the case of a European, whose foreign lineaments would, in those savage Asiatic districts, even in periods of peace, be regarded by an Oriental with mistrust, and must singularly displease him in time of war" (26).  This is the reason he disguised himself as a dervish.
* Ottomans and the Hajj: "It is an old custom of the Turkish embassy to accord a small subsidy to the hadjis and dervishes, who every year are in the habit of passing in considerable numbers through Persia toward the Turkish empire... The consequence was, that the hotel of the embassy received guests from the most remote parts of Turkestan" (28).
* Orientalism: "Words so unselfish proceeding from the mouth of an Oriental much surpised me" (29).
** "The Oriental does not understand the thirst for knowledge, and does not believe much in its existence" (32).
* Tajiks vs. Uzbeks: "The hostility of the Osbeg (Tartar) tribes of CEntral Asia to the Tadjiks (the ancient Persian inhabitants) had long previously been known to me..." (31).
* Bukhara's bad rep: "... Bokhara, the only city in CEntral Asia that I really feared from having learned the unhappy lot of the travelers who had peceded me tither" (32).
* How Vambery gets in with the Dervishes: "I told them, for instance, that I had long silently, but earnestly, desired to visit Turkestan (Centra Asia), not merely to see the only source of Islamite virtue that still remained undefiled, but to behold the saints of Khiva, Bokhara, and Samarcand" (32).

The Expedition Begins - Turkmen Lands
* Impression of his traveling companions (numbering 23): "... they are in reality the most honest people I shall ever meet with in those parts" (42).
* Heh - His disguise as a dervish does not really fool anyone; they can tell from his skin that he is high-born (51).
* Author runs into geopolitics before even getting out of Iran: Afghans and Turkmens in service of the Russians.  "How great, then, was my astonishment when I learned that this Afghan was ready for the voyage; that he would allow the hadjis to accompnay him, but that he objected bo my highness, whom he regarded as a secret emissary of the sultan, fearing lest he might lose his meanso f subsistence from the Russians should he venture to take such an individual on board his vessel" (54).
* More orientalism: "The Oriental, and particularly the Islamite, bred up in lies and treachery, always believes the very contrary of what a man shows particular earnestness in convincing him of..." (55).
* Russians and the Turkmen problem: "The Russian government makes, naturally, the greatest exertions and at the greatest cost to paralyze the predatory habits of the TUrkomans... The Russian ships cruise incessantly day and night in the Turkoman waters..." (60).
** Southernmost Russian possession: Ashourada.
** Turkmens in the Russian service: "Khidr Khan still continued to live in a tent in the middle of the semi-European colony; his functions consisted in using his influence with the TUrkomans generally to prevent their piracies, or at least in conveying ot the Russians intelligence of any intended expedition... This Khidr Khan, though once so good a Mussulman, had formed at an early date acquaintance with the genreous vodki (Russian brandy)..." (61).
* Slavery: Not so relative a term?  "... a Persian slave, heavily laden with chains..." (70).
** "I was astonished to find how many of my fellow-travelers, the poorest of the poor, in spite of the noble hospitality of which they had been partakers, were already weary of the Turkomans; for it would be, they said, impossible for men having the least sentiment of humanity to be eye-witnesses any longer of the cruel treatment to which the wretched Persian slaves had to submit.  'True, the Persians are heretics, and they tormented us terribly in our journey through their country; bu twhat the poor wretches here suffer is really too much'" (81-82).
** "No other termination to his sufferings than the payment of a ransom by his friends; and, failing this, he is liable to be sold, and perhaps __hurried off to Khiva and Bokhara__!" (82).
** Describes the miserable state of Russian slaves, who die in captivity (105).
* "No other termination to his sufferings than the payment of a ransom by his friends; and, failing this, he is liable to be sold, and perhaps __hurried off to Khiva and Bokhara__!" (82)
* People begin to question his Dervish-ness, suspecting he is an Ottoman agent; but then never think he is European (78).
* Reach of the Bukhara madrassas: "I found particular advantage in the friendship of Kizil Akhond (his proper name was Mollah Murad), a Turkoman 'savant' of high distinction, with whom I was upon the best footing and whose recommendtation procurred access for me everywhere.  Kizil Akhond had in his time, __when sudying in Bokhara__, fallen upon a work in the Osmanil Turkish language, a sort of comment or explanation of sentences and expressions in the Koran" (73).
* Interesting stuff about how the Turkmen use Greek bricks they find from Alexander's time to build a mosque (77).
** Goes into local Alexander myths: "According to Kizil, the wall had been erected by the genii (djinns), at the command of the mighty sovereign Alexander.  'Alexander,' he said, 'was a more pious Mussulman than we are, and therefore all subterranean spirits, whether they would or no, owed him allegiance'" (79).
* Even among the tribes, the mullah enjoys incredible respect: ""Nor was the difference great between the manner in which he was received in his own tents and those of strangers... Even in the settlments of hostile tribes he was not only treated with honorable distinction, but laden with presents..." (80).
* Vambery's is not a purely negative orientalism by any means.  One of the author's fellow hadjis was robbed in a mosque.  "After a long search in every direction, as no discovery was made, the ishan (priest) declared that he would at once utter his malediction upon the thief should he not restore the stolen property.  Before twenty-four hours had expired the conscience-stricken criminal came forward, bringing with him not only the stolen property, but a present as atonement.  I venture to recommend this practice to the London detectives as as a substitute for their present system" (80-81).
* These here parts have their own rules.  Author is about to buy himself a camel to cross the desert, "... but I was dissuaded by Hadji Bilal and Sultan Mahmoud, who remarked that an appearance of wretchedness calculated to excite compassion was the best guarantee for safety among these nomads...  They named several of the hadjis who were well provided with means, and who, nevertheless, for the sake of prudence, were obliged to wander on in rags and on foot " (87).
* The Khan of Khiva's defense is the desert itself; relates that years before a Farangi was taken to Khiva and managed to take notes of where all the wells were, which was a major security risk (118).
* Out of our minds (crossing the desert to Khiva): "This evening my appetite left me. I had not the slightest craving for even the smallest piece of bread: my sensations were those of extreme debility; the heat of the day was indescribable" (188).
* Alexander: "Quite out of breath, I fell down before the tomb, which was thirty feet long, and ornamented with rams' horns, the signs of supremacy in Central Asia" (140).
* Huge tombs: "The Orientals love to dignify their saints also with the attribute of bodily size.  In Persia I have remarked several giant graves; and even in Constantinople, on the Asiatic shore of the Bosphorous, on the so-called Mount of Joshua, exists a long tomb which the TUrks venerate as that of Joshua of the Bible, but the Greeks as that of Hercules" (140).
* Weak rule of the khans: "I made inquiries, and found that we were taking a circuitous way for the sake of security.  The Ozbeg met yesterday had warned us to be on our guard, for that the Tchaudors were in open rebellion against the khan, and that their alamans were often making forays on these frontiers" (147).
* Ethnicity: There is definitely an understood difference between Turkomans and Ozbegs. "Although they [Turkomans] have dwelt now several centuries side by side with the Ozbegs, they detest the manners and customs of the latter, avoid their company, and, alghouth of kindred origin and tongue, an Ozbeg is as much a stranger in their eyes as a Hottentot is in ours" (149-150).

Khiva
* "Had the Eastern poets turned their lyres here, they would have found a more worthy theme than in the horrid wastes of Persia!" (150).
* Khivan khan's reputation: "I was well aware that the Khan of Khiva, whose cruelty was displeasing to the Tartars themselves, would, in case he felt any distrust, become far severer to me than the other Turkomans.  I had heard that the khan was in the habit of at once making slaves of all strangers of doubtful character; that he had, not long before, so treated a Hindustani, who claimed to be of princely origin, and who was now, like the other slaves, employed in dragging along the artillery carriages" (151).
* Khiva and the hajj: "For years so numerous a troop of hadjis had not arrived in Khiva.  All stared us in astonishment..." (152).
* Function of the caravansarai (interesting): "In accordance with the custom of the country, we dismounted at the caravanserai.  This served also as a custom-house, where the new arrivals of men and merchandise are subjected to severe examination" (158).
* "My first step was to go to Shukrullah Bay, who, without filling any functions, occupied a cell at that time in the medresse of Mehemmed Emin-Khan, the finest edifice in Khiva" (154).
** Shakrullah Bay's reaction: "In God's name, effendi, what induced you to come to this fearful country, and to come to us, too, from that paradise on earth, from Stamboul?" (154).
* Khan addresses public grievances personally: "... crowded with petitioners of every class, sex, and age.  They were attired in their ordinary dresses, and many women had even children in their arms, waiting to obtain a hearing; for no one is required to inscribe his name, and he who has managed to force his way first is admitted" (157).
* Power of the Ottomans: "... for my personal security, I had with me a firman, bearing at the top the tugra (seal of the sultan).  I then handed him my printed pass.  On receiving this sign of paramount sovereignty, he kissed it reverently, rubbed it on his forehead, rose to place it in the hands of the khan, and, returning almost immediately, told me to step into the hall of audience" (158).
** LOL: "A man might place his life in jeopardy who should assert the fact that the sultan has head and beard shaved a la Fiesko, and clothes made for him at Paris by Dusetoye" (163).
** Too good to make up: A Khivan asks the author "... whether the great sultan really had his each day's dinner and supper forwarded to him from Mecca, and whether they passed to his palace from the Kaaba in one minute.  Ah! if the good Ozbegs only knew how much Chateau Lafitte and Margot garnished the sovereign's table in the reign of Abdul Medjid!" (164).
* Author's attitude toward the Khivan khan: "When I found myself again alone within the four walls of my cell I drew a long breath, not a little pleased to find that the khan, who in appearance was so fearfully dissolute, and who presents in every feature of his countenance the real picture of an enervated, imbecile, and savage tyrant, had behaved to me in a manner so unexceptionable; and that, so long as my time permitted, I could now traverse the khanat in all directions unmolested" (160).	
* Functionality of the mosque: "What in Europ idlers seek in coffee-houses they find in Khiva in the courts of the mosques.  These have in most cases a reservoir of water, and are shaded by the finest palms and elm-trees" (164).
* Khan considers self to be a severe defender of religion: "The khan has affixed the punishment of death not only to adultery, but to other offenses against religion, so that in the first years of his reign the ulemas were even obliged to cool his religious zeal..." (168).
* Reports that many of the dervishes are opium addicts (183).  "In Khiva, beng is the favorite narcotic; and many are addicted to this vice, because indulgence in wine and spiritous liqours is forbidden by the Koran, and any infringement is a sin punished by the government with death" (184).
* Khiva - Bukhara road: "Although the way between Khiva and Bokhara had been described to me as a frequented one, we had as yet, wit hthe exception of the frontier-watchers and the nomads who were roaming about, not met a single traveler" (186).

Bukhara
* Government apparatus: "In Khakemir there are but 200 houses... We were obliged to pass the night here, that the tax-collector (Badjghir) and reporter (vakanuviz), informed of our arrival in accordance with the law, might be in a position to complete their report of search and examination outside the city.  The very same day a messenger went express, and the following one, very early in the morning, arrived three of the emir's officers, with faces full of official dignity and importance, to levy upon us the imposts and duties, but more especially to learn tidings concerning the adjoining countries" (199).
** There is a bureaucratic apparatus at work here (where it its paper trail?) - "... Hadji Salih gave him explanations as to my rank, my character, as well as the object I had in view in my journey, all of which he noted down carefully, accompanying the act with a look at me and a shake of the head full of meaning.  When th ecollector had finished with us, the functions of the vakanuvisz (writer of events) began.  He first took down the name of each traveler, with a detailed description of his person, and then whatever information or news each might have it in his power to give" (200).
* The Tekkie Vambery stays at in Bukhara: "I had fallen, without having remarked it, upon the chief nest of Islamite fanaticism in Bukhara... in the tekkie the emir's orders were inoperative" (204).
* Merchandise at the bazaar: "I kept close to my companions, casting as I passed glances at the booths, which contain, with a few articles from the other countries in Europe, fancy goods and merchandise, more especially of Russian manufacture" (207).
* Description of the Naqshbandi: "... dervishes of the order of the Nakishbendi, of whom this city is the place of origin and the principle abode.  Never shall I forget that scene when those fellows, with their wild enthusiasm and thier high conical caps, fluttering hair, and long staves, danced round like men possessed, bellowing out at the same tiem a hymn, each strophe of which was first sung for them by their gray-bearded chief" (210).
** //Naqshbandi... singing and dancing?//
* Comparing Bukhara and Khiva: "They praised me, but not a farthing did I ever get from them; and the semblance of sanctity in this nation presented a singular contrast with the genuine piety and benevolence of the Khivan Ozbegs" (212).
* Conolly and Stoddart: "The sad fate of these two martyrs has continued to remain, as I remarked, a secret even in Bokhara..." (212).
* There is a book bazaar: "I then proceeded to the book bazar, which contains twenty-six shops.  A printed book is here a rarity" (215).
* Guinea worm in Bukhara? "... but another circumstance doubled my sufferings - the apprehension of the rishte (filaria Medinensis), by which, during the season, one person in ten is attacked.  This obliged me to be continually drinking warm wateror tea.  This affection is quite usual, and is treated with as much indifference by those residing in Bokhara during the summer season as colds are with us;.  one feels, at first, on the foot, or on some other part of the body, a tickling sensation, then a spot becomes visible whence issues a worm like a thread.  This is often an ell long, and it ought some days after to be carefully wound off on a reel.  This is the common treatment, and occasions no extraordinary pain; but if the worm if broken off, an inflammation ensues, and instead of one, from six to ten make thier appearance, which forces the patient to keep his bed a week, subjecting him to intense suffering.  The more courageous have the rishte cut out at the very beginning.  The barbers in Bokhara are tolerably expert in this operation." (218-219).
* Bukhara the city and Islam: "I often heard it affirmed that 'Bokhara is the true support of Islam.' The title is too weak; it should rather be termed the 'Rome of Islam,' since mecca and Medina are its Jerusalem.  Bukhara is aware of her superiority, and plumes herslelf upon it in the face of all other nations of Islam; yes, even before the sultan himself, who is yet acknowledged as the official chief of religion; but he is not so readily pardoned for having suffered so much to be corrupted in his territories by the influence of the Frenghis" (220-221).
** //Khiva, which is not competing for Islamic cred., revers the Sultan, while Bukhara holds itself superior//
* Administration: the Rais. "Each city has its reis, who, with a cat-o'-four-tails in his hand, traverses the streets and public places, examines each passer-by in teh principles of Islamism, and sends the ignorant, even if they be gray-bearded men of threescore years, for periods varying from eight to fourteen days, to the boy's school; or he drives them into the mosques at the hour of prayer" (222-223).
** "Every trace of gladness and cheerfulness is banished from those circles where the influence of religion and the system of surveillance are so tyrannically felt.  The emir's spies force their way even into the sanctuaries of families, and woe to the man who permits himself to offend against the forms of religion or the authority of the sovereign" (223).
* Religiosity of Amir Muzaffar al-Din Khan: "He carries out strictly the political principles of his father, adn in his capacity as mollah and pious Musulman is the declared enemy of every innovation, even when he may be convinced of its utility" (224).
** Portrays the lifestyle of the amir as extremely austere, destroying palaces instead of seizing them.  "The expression 'princely table' is inapplicable to Bokhara, where one and the same dish satisfies prince, official, merchant, mechanic, and peasant" (227).

[[Manuscripts Index]]

> Qārī Raḥmat Allah ibn ʿĀshūr Muhammad al-Bukhārī mutakhallis bih Vażiḥ, Majmua (personal notebook)

مجموعۀ قاری رحمت الله بخاری
[[Semenov|Semenov, ed., Sobranie Vostochnykh Rukopisei Akademii Nauk Uzbekskoi SSR]] 5, p. 420; 4147, 262

By same author:
* [[Vażiḥ, Tuḥfat al-Aḥbāb fi Taẕkirat al-Āṣḥāb]]
* [[Vāżiḥ, Gharāīb al-Khabar fi ʿAjāīb al-Safar (al-Biruni 2106)]]

General Observations
* Vazih was a very curious fellow, it seems.  Many of these pages discuss far-off places and exotic ideas like the equator (36b) (خط استوا).  Excerpts about different places (e.g. دریای فرات - p. 38b, جبل لكام p. 37b excerpted from a wide variety of texts.

Permissibility of Poetry (p. 18).

List of manuscripts copied by Vazih: اسامیً کتابهایی که راقم مراقم نوشته تماماً (p. 23)
* //note: I have added dashes to separate the different works; the author did so as well in the original manuscript except with red lines above each work//
* (1) یک حکمة العین - یک ملا عبد الحکیم بر عقاید - دو ملا عبد الحکیم بر حاشیه - یک متون - یک شرح ملّا
* (2) تهذیب مع اسبابش - یک گلستان - بهارستان - جنّة الخلد - نگارستان جُوَینی - مقامات حریری
* (3) حیوة القلوب - اختیارات مجلسی - رسالۀ توحیدیه - کتاب جامع - پنج بیاض - مقیم خانی
* (4) اسرار قاسمی - مجمع الغرایب - انشاءات یوسفی - مجمع المحاضر و الوثایق - معرفة المذاهب
* (5) قانونچه - مقدمة اللغة زمخشری - مجموعه الادعیه - شرح قصیدۀ برده - دو قصیدۀ برده
* (6) قصیدۀ بانت سُعاد مع شرح - مفاتیح [مغالیق] - سوزگذاز نوعی - سه صفای حوزه - چار عین ممدوده
* (7) رسالۀ حاتمی در اصطرلاب - الواح الجواهر - تحفه المعصومین - مجموعۀ طب - موجز القانون - مقامات غویثه
* (8) اخوند شیخ بر ملا جلال - مولوی شریف جدید بر ملا جلال - ملّا احمد بر حکمة العین - حقایق الاسرار شرح قانونچه
* (9) یک مجموعۀ متفرّقه - براکلوس - تنگلوشاهی - جواهر نامه - متیسّر الطبّا - اخلاق محسنی
* (10) جامع الحکایت - دفعه جامع الحکایت - مجمع الوقایع - دو جامع عباسی - دفعه یک بیاض مجمع المعارف
* (11) دو حلیّة المتقین - جامع الروز - دفعه یک حیله - رسالۀ سعدیه مع حدیث - دو مجموعۀ طب - جنات الخلود
* (12) دو تذکره الشعرأ - بیاض عربی - مجموعۀ میرزا وصال - تذکره الشعرأ مؤلف

Выписка о Индии (excerpt from هفت اقلیم من نفسیه) (p. 33b-35)
* (1) مخفی نماند که هندوستان مملکتی است در غایت طول و عرض متوطانش
* (2) اکهر بت پرستند و در میان ایشان نیز اختلاف بسیار است و حیوانات
* (3) غریب الاشکال عجیب التمثیل از طیور و دواب و جانوران آبی بسیار است
* (4) و معادن و نباتاتِ نافعه لا تعد و لا تحصی و ایضا چند ان خوبی که دریندیار ست
* (5) در هیچ مملکتی نیست از عبد الله بن سلام منقول ست که شادی را دَه جزو
* (6) افریده اند نه جزو آنرا بهندوستات و یکجزو را بباقی جهان داده اند و یکی از خوبیهای
* (7) هندوستان انست که مسافر را اجتیاج بزاد و سرای نیست چه د رهر منزلی
* (8) خوراک معلف چهار پا و محلّ آسایش موجود است و سلسلۀ آمد و رفت از
* (9) یکدیگر کسته نمیگردد خصوصاً زمستانکه از غایت اعتدال هوا تردّد 
* (10) بیشتر ست

List of madrasas in Bukhara (p. 47b)

List of sarays in Bukhara (p. 48)

List of Qazi posts مواضع قاضی میشد گیً بخارای شریف (p. 48)
* (1) بخارا - سمرقند - قرشی - دیزخ - اورگوت - پنجه کینت - چلک - کَرکی
* (2) ینگی قورغان خطای - پنجشنبه - خطرچی - کتّه قورغان - ضیأ الدین - نور اتا
* (3) میغ هزاره - اُخم - کوه پایه - چیم یرتی تپه - غجدوان - کامات - شافرکام - کام ابو مسلم
* (4) خُتفر - پیرمست - سامجن - خیراباد - مزار شریف - شمالی رود - قراکول
* (5) اوستی - بِتک - فرب - چارجوی - نرزم - بُرده لیغ - خواجه جانباز
* (6) ضامن - اوره تپه - اُورمیتن - چراغچی - یکّه باغ - کرمینه - خزار
* (7) کِلف - بایسون - شیراباد - ده نو - یورچی - سرجوی - سر آسیا - ریگر - قره تاغ
* (8) حصار - قورغان تپه - کولاب - بلجوان - قبادیان - قره باغ 
* (8-9) closing line fully decipherable but unintelligible: بشیر کنش خلچ 

Discussion of peculiarities of Iranian Farsi (p. 55-)
* در محاورات اهل ایران و بعضی کنایات و اصطلاحات که شعرا ذکر آن نموده اند (p. 55).



[[Manuscripts Index]]

> Qārī Raḥmat Allah ibn ʿĀshūr Muhammad al-Bukhārī mutakhallis bih Vażiḥ, Tuḥfat al-Aḥbāb fi Taẕkirat al-Āṣḥāb

Edited version: Vażiḥ, Qārī Raḥmat Allah ibn ʿĀshūr Muhammad al-Bukhārī. Tuḥfat al-Aḥbāb Fi Taẕkirat al-Āṣḥāb. Edited by A. M. Mirzoev. Dushanbe: Izd-vo “Donish,” 1977.

General Observations
* Organized alphabetically by تخلص
* Note that this work is paginated every page (as opposed to by leaf)

!!![[Moujani and Amr Yazdan Ali Mardan, eds., Fihrist-i Nosakh-i Khati-i Farsi-i Institui Asar-i Khati-i Tajikistan]]
تحفه الاحباب فی تذکره الاصحاب p. 112; 483
قاری رحمت الله ابن عاشور محمد البخاری متخلص به واضح
* Author lived 1817 - 1893. Book written 1864-1870.
* This is a poetical biography / excerpts type text. Interesting because it includes Iranian and Central Asian authors. It also includes information on a circle of Khoqandi poets.
* From this page forward there are lots of other poetical biographies as well - tons of em. About Tajik poets in the late 18th and 19th century.

!!!Introduction
* There are so many titans of the arts in Turan that they are impossible to count (p. 3): درینمدّت یکصد و بیست دو سال عروس مملکت توران زمین در عقد تصرّف سلاطین متغطیّه [=منقطیه؟] در آمده سال تا سال مُلک آباد و اهل فضل و کمال در هر عهدی چنان ازیندیار بظهور میرسد که مُحاسِب عقل و وهم را احصای آن در خیال محال

!!!The Biographies (alphabetical by takhallus)
Ada: سلطانخواجه شیخ الاسلام سمرقندی (p. 12-14)
* death date (13): 1250
* Takhallus (12): ادا
* Assuming based on nisbat that he was born in Samarkand
* Father (12): خواجه عبد الله احرار
** Judging by the nature of father's titles (قطب السالکین etc) he was a sufi.  Apparently a very famous one at that as the author notes that no description of his exploits is necessary: احتیاج بشرح و بیان ندارد
* Entry has a pretty ornate passage lauding the amir of Bukhara for his incredible generosity (12).
* Lived during the age of Umar Khan of Khoqand (p. 13): و محصور در عهد حکومت عمر خان والی خوقند قائد تقدیر چندی زمام ارادش را بدان صوب کشید
** Apparently Umar Khan's largesse attracted him to the Khoqand court.  Gave him the title "king of the poets" (p. 14): و خطاب ملک الشعرائ یافته و ترقیات عظمه او را دست داده
* After that he returned to Bukhara and became the Shaykh al-Islam (13).
* Note that he composed poetry both in Farsi and Turki (p. 13): خواجۀ مذکور در فنّ شعر گوئی از فارسی و ترکی فارس مضمار بلاغت و فصاحت در هر دو زبان دیوان تمام کرده و قصائد غرّا نیز بسی گفته
** Particularly famous for the qasida named ناله و افغان (afghan, not Afghan), which was printed (مطبوع افتاده) (p. 13).
* Ada was also reputed to have performed miracles, but the author has no examples: و خواجه مذکور را خوارق عادات نیز منقولست که این رساله تحمل امثال آنها ندارد
* Note: Ada is also mentioned in [[Muntakhab al-Tavarikh|Asimov (ed) Muntakhab at-Tavarikh (Dushanbe 1983 edition)]]:
** * Sufi influence on Hakim Khan: "Большую роль в судьбе Хакимхана сыграл внук Фазил бия (по дочери) ишан Султанхан Ходжа Ахрари, который, будучи ишаном, имел большое влияние на правителей на только Ура-Тюбе, но и Бухары и Коканда... По мнению Хакимхана, в Бухаре в то время не было более популярного и авторитетного человека, чем ишан Султанхан ходжи (л. 689).  Он был в самых дружеских отношениях с отцом автора, к которому часто приезхал в Ура-Тюбе и подолгу там гостил.  В своем сочинении Мухаммед Хакимхан и своего родного отца, и ишана почтительно называет "киблагох" (отец)".  Прямых родсвенных связей автора рукописи или отца с ишаном Султанханом пока не установлено" (25).

Atashi رفیع المقامی میر بقا خواجه (p. 13-16)
* Takhallus (13): آتشی
* Noble ancestor (13): مولانا عنايت الله أخوند
* In the service of (taught by) (14) عطأ الله خواجه مشهور چپّه نویس
** On Chappa Navis, see [[Taẕkirat al-Khaṭṭāṭīn-i Mīrzā Muḥammad Sharīf al-Mutakhallas bil-Żīāʾ (al-Biruni 1304/III)]]
* Entry makes big point of his studies (14): در اوائل شباب تحصیل علم مشغول بسیار صاف ذهن و پاک فهم در حسن خلق و همّت بیهمتا و در شیوۀ انصاف و مروت او را ید بیضا شرافت نسب را باکر است
* Seriousness and melancholiness (sometimes from his studies) prompted him to write poetry (14).

Ansab منصور خواجه نقشبندی (p. 16-18)
* Takhallus: انسب
* Descended from (16): خواجه بها الحق بخاری
* Always wrote / spoke about independence, tyranny: دم از استقلال و استبداد میزد

Akbar اکابر خواجه (p. 18-19)
* His actual name is اکبر but he is known as اکابر خواجه
* Started as a Quran reader:
* After completing his studies he became a mudarris (18): بعد از فراغ تحصیل و ختم علوم مقرّره بتدریس بعضی از مدارس منصوب و بافاضۀ و افادۀ طلاب مشغول بود

Afzah مختار مخدوم بخاری (p. 19-20)
* Takhallus: افضح 
* Antinomian dervish (19): قندر نشرب از عالم سیر باطن شل کوکنار و افیون 

Irsi (p. 20-22)
* Takhallus: ارثی
* Traveled from Hisar to Bukhara to study (20): از ولایت حصار در بخارا تحصیل علم نموده
* His wittiness gained him the attention of the rulers; he also had qalandar tendencies (20): طبعش بمزاح و شوخی مایل با امرا و حکّام ملخوط و بسیار لااُبال و قلندر وضع بوده

Afghan ملا گل محمد بی افغان(p. 22-24)
* This poet comes from the ranks of the amirs (22): از جملۀ امرأ عظیم الشأن بوده
** and he served as a governor (22): مکانی بحکومت ولایتهای بزرگ مثل خطرچی و نوراتا منصوب بوده
*** Khatarchi per Dehkhoda: شهری بوده است در سمت غربی سمرقند بفاصلۀ ده فرسنگ
**** Unclear if this province fell under Russian possession in 1868.
* Followed in the poetic tradition of Bidal (22): مستعّد ان عصر تتبّع اشعار میرزا عبد القادر بیدل نموده
* This poet was also very much in the tradition of "beloved" poetry; he fell in love with a particular slave boy (22): سودای عشق ماه رخسار ان اکثر بر مزاجش غالب خصوصاً عادل خان نام غلامی داشته در حسن و جمال یوسف مصر سباحت و ایاز اقلیم ملاحت
** Very sexual innuendo - the slave boy is so beautiful he overpowers the fortitude to resist (22): باحسن صورت و لطف سیرت او زمام عقل و شکیبالی از دست رفته بجز مشاهدۀ گل رخسار او بچیز دیگر نمیپرداشته
** But there is a tragedy; using very flowerly language, author conveys that the boy died (23).
** The death of his beloved sent him into heartbreak (23): بخاک حسرت فروریخت و زمانۀ غدّار از رهگذار این سانحه جانکاه غبار ندامت و ادبار بر فرق آن عاشق افکار ریخت
* Broken, Afghan quit his job with the army and wrote poetry about his beloved full time (23): بالاخیر ترک سپاهی گری نموده

Ishan محمد امین خواجه شیخ الاسلام جویباری (p. 24-26)
* Aside from holding the rank of Shaykh al-Islam, this individual is also descended from the Juybari shaykhs (24): از جانب پدری بحضرت هدایت پناه خواجه امام ابو بکر جویباری است
* He also held two notable bloodlines on his mother's side (24-25): و از طرف مادر بدو شعبه منقسم میشود از یکجانب بحضرت خواجه عبیدالله احرار و از یکطرف دیگر بحضرت مولانا خواجگی کاسانی دهبیدی قدس الله ارواحی که هر کدام قطب وقت و غوث زمان بودند
** Possible that کاسانی should be کاشانی
* Seems that he was very familiar with the history of the prophets, etc (25).
* His house was always filled with guests coming to visit him (25): هر شب ههمانهای ایشان از صادر و وارد اصناف طوایف مملو و از طالبعلمان و قاریان قرآن و اهل احتیاج بسیار کس بودند
* Ishan had a habit of venturing out into the desert / field (صحرا) with other intellectuals to discuss high issues (25): هر روز همراه چندی از اهل علم و دانش سواره بسیر صحرا میبرامدند و زبان حال بدین مقال ترنّم داشت (followed by the prayer they would sing).
** @@description of Persianate high culture@@ (25): بر شطّ سواقی جاریات با جوارئ ساقیات مشغول عیش و عشرت و مشاعره و مناظره میبودند مذاکره و مباحثۀ هر نوع از اشعار و حکایات رنگین در میان می افتاد 
* Ishan is the maternal nephew of Ata (26).

A'raj ملا عبد الاحد خواجه بخاری (p. 26-29)
* Takhallus: اعرج
* Descendant of پادشاه خواجه قمچین زن (p. 26).
* Was familiar with soothsaying (27): و اوقاف رمل نیز نموده
* Family suffered from poverty; family too big for the money to go around (27): بعلت کثرت قلّت و فقر که نامش از جهان مدروس و مطموس باد ممتحن و مبتلا مع هذا اکثر العیال و معدوم الدخل
* He served as an imam and as a Masnavi Khwan (27): در سالف ازمان بحکم تحرک دستپای بامامت مساجد و مثنوی خاون مشغول بوده
** However after a year or two at that position he had an accident and hurt his leg preventing further work (27).
** Because of his infirmity he withdrew from society and was not really heard from; now he educates children in his home (27): در کنج خمول سر میبرد بکتابت و معلّمی اطفال و صحیح خوان مشغول ست

Amir محمد عمر خان والی بلدۀ خوقند (p. 29-31)
* Takhallus: امیر
* Muhammad Umar Khan (ruled 1810 - 1822)
* Renowned for his generosity to poets, etc., along with an unspecified deceased Amir (29).
* This Khoqandi khan is counted among the great poets (30): خان مذکور را بطائفۀ شعرا و فضلا محبتّی عظیم بوده
* Wrote his own divan in Turki and Farsi (30): و او را دیوانی ست بزبان ترکی و فارسی

Akmal شیر محمد خوقندی (p. 31-33)
* Takhallus: اکمل
* His bi-lingual works (32): از شعرای عمر خان والی فرغانه بهر دو زبان ترکی و فارسی و قصائد و غزلیّات و مقطعات بدیعه بسیار گفته
* He was a trusted confidant of Umar Khan (32):  او را در نزد خان مذکور اعتبار و مقدار تمام بوده

Afqar محمود خواجه بخاری (p. 33-37)
* Takhallus: افقر
* Exalted lineage (33): حضرت شاه قاسم انوار 
** From Dehkoda - full name:  سید علی بن نصربن هارون بن ابوالقاسم حسینی یا موسوی تبریزی ملقب به معین الدین یا صفی الدین و متخلص به قاسم و مشهور به قاسمی و شاه قاسم
*** Name of the Sufi shaykh under whom he trained (Sultan Sadr al-Din Musa d. 1291 of the Safavid order): سیر و سلوک دست ارادت به سلطان صدرالدین موسی بن شیخ صفی الدین سید اسحاق اردبیلی جد سلاطین صفویه داده و در خدمت آن پیر روشن ضمیر ریاضات بسیاری کشیده
*** Sufi, Poet, scholar of the 9th century hijri: عارفی است فاضل و شاعری است ماهر از اکابر صوفیه و عرفای قرن نهم هجری
*** Travels; began sufi training in Herat: در قزوین و سمرقند و گیلان و هرات و خراسان سیاحتها کرده
**** Also visited Balkh
*** Originally from a village near Nishapur; died 837 hijri: در اثنای مراجعت به وطن خود در قریه خرجرد یا قصبه ٔ لنکر جام از توابع نیشابور به مناسبت لطافت آب و هوا اقامت کرد و به سال 835 یا 837 یا 838 هَ . ق . در همانجا وفات یافت 
* Describing his training (33): تحصیل علوم رسمی نموده و علاوه بر آن در علم اوقاف و اعداد و نهر نقاشی و [لواحی] و تصویر از مشاهیر روزگار بوده و در شیوۀ خطّاطی یز در خوبی و ملاحت
* He was a very free person unburdened by pleasantries etc (34): از تکلفات رسمی و تقیّدات عرفی دامن احوالش مطهّر
* Composed in both Farsi and Turki (34).
* Wrote a work (a مثنوی) called خمسه عشر (p. 34): مثتوی ترتیب داده مسمّی بخمسه عشر مشتمل بر حکایات در روایات غریبه هر کدام از ان را به پانزده بیت تمام کرده
* He was a prolific traveller; he visited the grave of Ali, for instance (35): چندی بعزم سایحت سالک ممالک بعیده گردیده در هر بلاد و ملوک بصحبت حکام و ملوک رسیده
** Note that it does not say which grave of Ali he visited - Mazar-i Sharif or Iraq (35): علی ابن ابی طالب رضی عنه گردیده و بسی نتائج و فوائد از مواید احسان ان مَهبَط فیض الهی و مخزن فضل نامتنایی بدست در آورده
* Served as an Imam (35): در معزل خمول و عزلت منزوی و ساکن و بعلت کجروشیهای زمانۀ بیوفا ببهانۀ امامت بعضی از مساجد قری در کنف جدّ بزرگوار خود منطوی و متوطّن
* Can infer that he was a member of the Qadiriyya (35).
* He was also a mudarris; gathered students to him and payed them (35): چندی از طلبۀ علم را جمع ساخته مداخل و موارد خود را در آن مهسّم خیر خرج و صرف مینماید
* So he says a Qadiriyya prayer near his ancestor's grave (in Herat) 35

Amlah ملا میر عظیم بخاری (p. 37-39)
* Takhallus: املح
* Memorized the Quran at an early age and mastered tajwid (37): در اوایل شباب حافظ کلام ملک علّام گردیده
* He is also a top-notch poet - hence his inclusion here (37).

Baqa میر بقا خاواجۀ میرگانی (p. 39-40)
* Takhallus: بقا
* Sayyid; the family of sayyids he came from traditionally served as ra'is, sadr, and mirasad (39): از سادات  رضویه ابا عن جد بمناسب ارجمند صدارت و ریاست و میراسدئ بلدۀ فاخرۀ بخارا ی شریف معزّز و سزافراز میباشند
** Bosworth on the ra'is in eastern Islamdom during the middle ages (EI): "... the ra'is, whether appointed by an outside ruling body or not, was not simply a salaried official of the state but the representative of his town and its interests vis-a-vis the provincial or central government, above all, over questions of the taxation due from the town, and he could reprort back to the sultan's diwan if any of the state officials were grossly abusing their power locally."
*** "The ra'is recedes from mention in the history of the Persian lands by the time of the Mongol invasions, but it should be noted that the Al-i Burhan, the line of Hanafi ru'asa' in the Transoxianian city of Bukhara, held hereditary office there from the mid-6th/12th century well into th emiddle of the 7th/13th one, with the additional title, expressive of their religious leadership also in the city, of sadr al-sudur."
* Also detailed the posts Baqa in particular held, including qazi in various provinces and ra'is in Bukhara and then qazi in Bukhara until he died (39): در عهد دولت حضرت امیر مرحوم بقضأ ولایت قرشی و سمرقند و غجدوان و درین عصر نیز از یمن لطف و رأفت حضرت ظل آلهی رام دولت بریاست بخارا و از ان بقضای آلهی موصول گردیده و وفات یافت
* Very generous in providing answers and help to those who came to him (39).

Bahar میرزا ربیع مخدوم بخاری (p. 40-41)
* Takhallus: بهار
* Taught in the madrasa زرگران - possibly in Bukhara but does not specify (40).
* Was a classmate of Vazih, the author (41): از شریک درسان راقم نامه است

Bibak عبد الباقی خواجه (p. 41-43)
* note that [[Afżāl al-Taẕkār fi Ẕikr al-Shuʿarāʾ va al-Ashʿār (al-Biruni 2303)]] has his name as "Muhammad Baqi."
* Takhallus: بیباک
* ancestor (41):  ملا میرک خواجۀ اعلم who is counted among the great scholars of Bukhara از مشاهیر دانشمندان بخارا ند
* Even tough he was very rich he had no need for the material comforts of the world (41).
* Became a mudarris after finishing his studies (41-42): بعد از فراغ از تحصیل علوم در مسند افاده نشسته بدرست گوئی طلاب مشغول اند
* Composed a book called سنبلستان (p. 42).

Bahjat (p. 43-44)
* Takhallus: بهجت
* A Khoqandi poet patronized by Muhammad Umar Khan (43): از شعرای خوقند ست در عهد دولت محمد عمر خان والی آنجا بسیار عروج و ترقّی نموده

Pari ملا محمد رجب حصاری (p. 44-45)
* Takhallus پری
* Composed beatiful poetry despite his illiteracy (44): با وجود عامی بودن در نظم اصناف شعر قدرت تمام داشته
** Not totally certain that Vazih really means that he was illiterate; he may mean that he was simply ignorant in the science of poetry.
* Seems that he was kind of a local court poet in Hisar (44): منظور حکّام و عّمال آنجا بوده شعارش بسیار خوب دلپذیر و شیرین و بی نظیر افتاده \\

Parsa محمد پارسا خواجۀ سلام آقاسی صدر (p. 45-48)
* Takhallus: پارسا
* Is a sayyid.
* sacred lineage of Sayyid Ata, i.e. most probably Yasawiyya (45-46): از اولاد امجاد حضرت قدوة الاولیأ الاصفیأ نهال جویبار مصطفوی ثمرۀ شاخسار مرتضوی سیّد اتا علیه الرحمه
* Yasawi lineage allowed him the title of Naqib, Sadr inter alia (46): خواجۀ مذکور همواره اجداد بزرگوارش بنماصب رفیعۀ نقابت و صدارت و بشرف مواصلت و مصاهرت سلایطین و دار الفاخرهۀ مفتخر و مباهی و خود نیز بطریقۀ اسلاف کرام منصوب بعمل صدارت پادشاهی و مورد نوازشات و تلطفات حضرت ظل آلهی بسیار فاضل و دانشمند و حافظ کلام ربّانی 
** DeWeese, “The Descendants of Sayyid Ata and the Rank of Naqīb in Central Asia,
* In the age of the previous amir Parsa served as an Ilchi (46): در عهد سلطنت حضرت امیر مرحوم اکثر برسمبرسم سفارت بایلچیگری ولایت مأمور میگردید و در ادراک محتملات و متحملات کلام حاضر و تیّار بود
** According to Basir the last part of that sentence means "on top of the affairs of the province."
* In this entry Vazih relays a couple of anecdotes, which is in itself interesting:
** Describes a majlis held by Parsa in his home (46): شخصی از فضلا نقل نمود که شبی باجماعتی از اهل علم و کمال بهانۀ مومی الیه مهمان شده بودیم
*** They discussed scholarly issues from every field (47): از مقولات علمیّه از هر باب مباحثه و مکامله میشد
*** The point of the anecdote seems to be a play on words presented by Parsa when an individual brought up the topic of corruption brought by love of worldy things (46) (دوستی دنیا); he connected that phrase to دینار و طلا اصل و بنیاد هر گناهست (p. 47).
*** Everyone was astonished by Parsa's erudition on this issue (46-47): از فطانت زهن و لطافۀ طبع او خاضر انرا حیرت بعجبی دست داده
** The second anecdote concerns a certain Indian alim (مولوی عاصی هندوستانی) who had become famous in Bukhara; seems that he refused to reveal his name or origin (47): و مولوی عاصی هندوستانی که مشهور بین جمهورست حاضر بود این مولوی درین چند سال در بخارا با اهل فضل و علم مشهور و ممخلوط بود مطلقا نام خود را و ولایت خود را نگفته بود
*** The Indian alim in the face of insistence offers his name in the form of a riddle that had to do with specifying connected and disconnected Arabic letters; Parsa is so smart that he guesses the right answer immediately (Iblis) - though obviously Iblis is not his real name so Parsa solved the riddle but Hindustani kept his real name secret (47): نام تو ابلیس بوده است
**** However, his real name is مقبول, (his takhallus is عاصی, which is also in this tabaqat), which also follows the rules of the riddle, so Parsa basically scored a huge public burn on Asi (48).
* Died in 1270 (48).
* Wrote poetry in the age of "Turaki" (identity unclear) in the Bukharan province of Karmina (50): 
** 	The poem itself contains an abjad date, presumably specifying the date of the hakim's rulership of Karmina (50): تأریخ دولت او جستم ز عقل گفتا، در قرعۀ منجم گفتا البو المظفّر

Parsa محمد پارسا خواجه مفتی عسکر صدر (p. 48-50)
* Takhallus and name: پارسا
* Oldest son and student of (48): داملا عنایت الله خواجۀ قاضی کلان
* Served as a tutor for the previous amir and another guy (Hazrat Iskandar) and as a result received high station (49): بر حقایق و دقایق معقولات و منقولات واقف علا الخصوص بتربیت امیر مرحوم و جناب اعلی سکندر مکانی باقصی الغایات کمالات و ترقیّات رسیده
** As a result he gained very high station amongst the ulama (49): محسود اقران گشت و منصب ممیّزی و کتاب خواندن علما که از مخصوصات علمأ عظام بود نیز بایشان مفوّض و محوّل شد
* Here Vazih offers a paralel story of naysaying and jealousy in Aurangzeb's court: During the era of Aurangzib (of Hindustan) Mirza Abu Talib Hakim had the title of king of the poets (49): در عهد اورنگزیب چون منصب ملک الشعرایی بمیرزا ابو طالب حکیم رسیده و اورا بزر کشیدند 
** The Indian poet's takhallus was Kilim (کلیم) (p. 49).
* Much like that anecdote about India (Kilim) he had many naysayers and enemies (49): و درین عهد نیز حریفان ظریف بامثال این نکات حاصدانه و کلمات ناانصافانه متکلّم و مترنّم بودند
* Serving as the tutor of the amir gets him appointed as the military mufti (49): از تربیت شاهنشاهی در آوان شباب بمنصب تدریس خواجه دولت و مفتی عسکریه از از وظائف علماء متقدم بود سرافراز گردید
* Breadth of his knowledge (49): بالجمله جناب مشار الیه در علوم رسمی و طِب و رمل و فرایض و اکثر علوم 
* Served as an ambassador in both Ottoman and Hindustan (49-50): بسفارت ولایت روم مأمور شده رفته و در بازگشت بولایت ممبی هندوستان وفات یافت

Taqi میرزا محمد تقی طهرانی (p. 50-54)
* Takhallus and name (50, 51): تقی; also known as هفت قلم
* Came to Marv with the Qajar army, taken prisoner by the Turkmen, ended up in Bukhara as a slave (50): از ولایت مذکور همراه قوشون قاچاریه بعنوان نویسنده گی و میرزائی بعزم مقابلۀ ترکمانیّه بولایت مرو آمده  بعد از تلاقی فریقین چون لشکر قاچاریه شکست یافته میرزای مزبور برسم اسیری افتاده ببخارا آمده
** poem comparing his bondage to that of Joseph (50): در مصر روزگار تمیزی نمانده است، ورنه مشخّص است که یوسف غلامیست
* Ends up in the service of the Qushbigi (50): بخذمت امارت پناه وزارت دستگاه محمد شاه قوشبیگی رسیده 
* He is one of the Sayyids of Iran (50): میرزای مذکور از نجیبزاده گان و سادات آن ولایت بوده
* Trained in Tehran; in particular he was a calligrapher (50-51): در طهران تحصیل علم نموده و حاوی اکثر کمالات ظاهری و باطنی بوده علی الخصوص در صنعت نقاشی و تذهیب و در فنّ خوش نویسی هفت قلم مشوهور بسرعت آن غایت مهارت وجودت داشت
** But also had other expertises (51): جوانی خوش صحبت عالی مشرب استعمال کُتُبِ لغت تواریخ و قصص و اشعار بسیار نموده
* Became very sick with an illness (51): بمرض قولنج مبتلا و اکثر ازین مَمَر دلش در ورطۀ اندوه و عناد خاطرش بجانب مسکن معهود و وطن مآلوف میکشید
* When he was sick they freed him and sent him back to Iran (51).

Jalal ملا تورسون باقی مخدوم بخاری (p. 54-57)
* Takhallus: جلال
* From the Juybari guzar (but probably not from the famous family) (54): از گذر جویبار مردی بوده
* Lots of poetical excerpts, but not very much biographical information.

Jalal  (p. 57-59)
* Takhallus: جلال
* Real name not given.  //not entered into database//
* One of Nasruddin Shah Qajar's court poets (57): از شعرای دولت ناصر الدین شاه والی طهر است
* Wrote praise poetry (مدح) of Nasruddin (57).

Jawhar محمد ابراهیم المروزی  (p. 59-61)
* Takhallus: جوهر
* From his nisbat we know that his ancestors were probably from Marv.
* Composed divans in both Farsi and Arabic (59): در دو زبان بعربی و فارسی دیوان تمام کرده
* Wrote a qasida dedicated to Husein (59-60): و کتابی مسمّی بطوفان البکأ در مصائب حضرت سید الشهدأ عبد الله الحسین ترتیب دادهو این قصیده را هم در آن کتاب در مدح حضرت عبّاس ابن ابی طالب بسیار نیکو گفته 
** //possible Shia leanings//

Jamali ملا میر جمال الدین خلمی (p. 61-63)
* Takhallus: جمالی
* Came from Khulum to study in Bukhara with his brother (61-62): از ان نجبباء ولایت مذکور همراه بتحصیل علوم ببخارا آمده
* Extremely allegorically and poetically implies that he died while he was still young (62): 
* Jamali was on his way to the Shah to pay his respect (آستان بوسی) but stayed in Karmina for some time as that was where the Amir was roosting (see Gulshani - there was a palace there) (62): و هنوز از نفحات بهار جوانی اش بمشام جانش نرسیده کتب فضا دیوان عمرش را از فاتحه بخاتمه رسانید
* Then he got permission to go to Bukhara (62). 
* Then he ended up in Hisar as well, served the hakim there, and died there (62): بصوب ولایت حصار عنان عزیمت معطوف گرداند و در آنجا با عبد الکریم خان حاکم آنجاآشنا شده اقامت گزید همدران ولایت وفات یافت
* Student of ilm, especially riddles and poetry (63): طالب علم رشید بود و در فنّ معّما و شهر نیز خوص بسیار میکرد

Hasrat میرزا عالم جان (p. 63-64)
* Takhallus: حسرت
* From Hisar
* Came to Bukhara for study in the time of (the rule of Amir Kabir and Sa'id) (61): از ولایت حصار در عهد دولت امیر کبیر و امیر سعید آمده
** Amir Kabir is the title of Danial Ataliq (?) and Amir Sa'id is Haydar; most likely that he emigrated in the early 19th century.
* Died of leprosy (بَرَص); his wife had to leave him as a result of this illness (61-62): گویند در اواخر عمر بمرض برص مبتلا شده و حلیلۀ او که نهایت تعشق با او داشته بعلّت مذکور افتراق نموده
* His poetry was known for being heartwrenching (حسرت انگیز) and some of his poetry samples seem to be about his separation from his wife (62).

Haziq  جنید الله مخدوم هروی (p. 63-68)
* Takhallus: حاذق
* Note: Abd al-Vahid Sarir mentions Haziq in [[his notebook|Qazi Abd al-Vahid Sarir Balkhi's Notebook (al-Biruni, 2260)]] as a colleague from his school days in the Tursonjan madrasa.
* هروی = from Herat
* Came to Bukhara (presumably from Herat) and enjoyed great favor at the court who patronized his studies (62-63): در اوائل عصر حکومت امیر مبرور ببخارا آمده بانواع تفقدات و نوازشات خسروانه سرافرازی یافته بافاضل و اکابر بخارا محشور و محسور تحصیل علم مقرّری نموده 
** //who is Amir Mabrur? Given that he later went to Umar's court, probably another title of Haydar//
* Trained to be a doctor, which was recognized with great acclaim (63): در علم طبابت نیز طبل دعوی زده بهمین مناسبت خودرا حاذق تخلّص نموده
* After some time he was summoned to Khoqand where he wrote a poem about Joseph and Zulaykha for the amir there (63): بعد از چند گاه بحکم تقدیر و آبخورش بخوقند رفته و قصّۀ یوسف زلیخا را بنام حاکم آنجا بنظم در آورده صلات وافره و انعامات کثیره یافته
** After the death of Omar Khan of Khoqand Haziq returns to Bukhara, where he again received all manner of honors (63).
* Ultimately, however, the sultan became suspicious and Haziq fled to Shahrisabz, where he was executed (63): بالاخیر بنابر امری از سطوت سلطانی متوهّم شده بشهرسبز رفته در آنجا بقتل رسید
* In addition to the usual praise, the author describes him as قلندر مزاج (p. 63).
* In every age there are examples of bad things befalling great men; Vazih is praising him further for the misfortune that befell him (63):
* Includes some verses about a chorbagh gifted to him by the amir (67): گویند حضرت امیر مرحوم و عدۀ چهار باغ باو نموده اند چون تأخیر یافته در مطالبۀ آن این قطعه را گفته
** چهار باغی که خسرو عالم، وعده فرموده اند آن نرسید
** فصل گل بیش نیست یکدو سه روز، که گلی خواهمش ز گلبن چید
** یا که آن جنّت ست و جنت را، تا نمیرد کسی نخواهد دید
*** I.e. sarcastically noting that perhaps the garden that the amir meant was heaven itself which he will not see before death.
* Haziq would verbally joust especially often with Makhdum Jalali (68).

Haji حاجی خان ولد بیرام علی خان (p. 68-69)
* Son of the Hakim of Marv (68).
* Came to Bukhara after the murder of his father and was greeted with great honor by the amir (68): حاجی تخلص و نام حاجی خان ولد بیرام علی خان حاکم مرو ست بعد از قتل پدر خود ببخارا آمده مورد الطاف نامتناهی شاهنشاهی گردیده با اکابر و افاضل بخارا مشهور و مخلوط بوده
* Studied the Islamic sciences under Damulla Mirak A'lam (68): در خذمت داملا میرک اعلم رسالۀ عروض و بعضی از علوم مشکله را گذارانیده
** Note that Mirak also taught Abu Nasr Tughi.
* Then for an unspecified reason he went to Najaf in Iran where he died (68): باز بنابر سببی از بخارا عازم ولایت ایران گردیده بنجف اشرف توطن گزیده همانجا وفات یافته
* Wrote poetry in praise of Amir Sa'id (i.e. Haydar) (68).

Hasan (p. 69-70)
* This indvidual was a courtesan of Bayram the Hakim of Marv - just like previous entry Haji (69): حسن بنام خود تخلّص مینموده از ندیمان بیرام علی والی مرو به هنر حکماگی مشهور بعد از قتل حاکم مذکور مشار الیه ببخارا آمده 
* Famous for his stone engraving; also known for jokes and witticism (69).
* After murder of the Hakim he went to Bukhara (69).
* He was especially close to the Juybari shaykhs (69): 
* Wrote a poem complaining about a bad poem (69): سر ما سرسری متراش و سر را وا مگیر از ما، که ما هم در دیار خود سری داریم سودای
** There is also a poem that someone else wrote in response to this couplet.

Hayrat
* Full name (70): حیرت تخلص... ملا عبد العزیز مخدوم ولد قاضی غنی بلخی است
* Shows up in multiple sources, including [[Marjānī, Wafiyyat al-Aslāf, 19th century]]
* Patronized by previous amir; appointed ra'is and qazi (70): در عهد دولت امیر مرحوم نوّر مرقده تربیت و نوازشات بسیار دیده و بمناصب رفیعه منعیه مثل قضا و ریاست رسیده 
* (cont.) A bibliophile - copied and edited volumes (70): از جنس کتب متقدمین خواه فارسی و خواه عربی در هر علم که باشد کتابی نمانده که بشرف مطالعۀ آن نه پیوسته و تصحیح اکثر آن در خواشی آنها از نوادر افکار دقّت شعار تحریر کرده

Habibi
* Name, scribing endeavors (71b): حبیبی نامش ملا حبیب الله از صحرا های بخارا تحصیل علم نموده کتاب فقه کیدانی و شرح عقاید نسفی و بعضی از کتابهای مختصر وقایه را نظم نموده و راحة العاشقین نام کتابی تصنیف ساخته مشتمل حکایات
* Still alive, serving as an imam (71b): الحال در قید حیات و بامامت مساجد صحرا مشغول 

Khamil
* Name, origin from Shahrisabz, born in Bukhara (72): خامل نام نامی اش عبد الرحمن اصلش از ولایت شهر سبز مولد ش در بخارا تحصیل علم نموده و ختم کردن
* (cont.) Spent much of his time in service and traveling; seems that he was something of a wine-drinking dandy who enjoyed the finer things (72): بعلّت قلّت و سستی طابع مبتلا اکثر اوقاتش مصروف کتابت وضعی متین و طبعی سلیم داشت بخذمت اکابر و اشراف رسیده اغلب زمان در سیاحت بلاد عمر بسر میبرد عاشق شرب لاابال و مجذوب و آراسته و آزاده میزیست
* (cont.) Afficionado of Bidal, Navoy, Jami, and Baba Sa'ib (//don't recognize that last one//) (72): معتقد اشعار میرزا عبد القادر بیدل و نوائی و مولوی جامی و بابا صائب
* (cont.) //very interesting Beloved passage//(72): هر چند سرش از سودای محبوبان خالی نبود لیکن زیاده پاک نظر و صاف اعتقاد مینمود
* Followed by a sufi vision involving Jami //revisit//.
* Ardent sufi, kept to himself, which earned him his nickname (72b): الحاصل مولای مشاری الیه شخصی بوده فاضل و کامل شعر گوی و شعر شناس و محّب طریقۀ درویشان و با مردم عامی و نادران کم اختلاط چون عنقا در اخیر عمر خود تحقیق تخلّص در زاویۀ قناعت و خمول بسر میبرد
* (cont.) That said, he did serve the prince (which one?) in Karmina (72b): چندی قسمت و تقدیر در سلک و دعا گویان و ملازمان حضرت ظل آلهی در ولایت کرمینه مسکن داشت باز از آنجا ببخارا 
* Died 1272.

Khumuli (see also: [[Tarjuma-i Ḥāl-i Qāẓī Jumʿa-Qul Khamūlī]])
* Opening - name, from an Uzbek tribe in Urgut (73): خمولی تخلّص ملا جمعه قل قاضی ولایت اورگوت از طائفه اوزبکیۀ بلدۀ مدکوره اعجوبۀ زمان و نادرۀ دوران سالها بقضای آنجا 
** (cont.) Except apparently Khumuli was a serious opium abuser (73):با وجود کِبَر سن بعلّت نشه کوکنار بنوعی گرفتار که چندین خدمتکار شب و روز بی توقّف مشغول کوفتن و صاف کردن کوکنار و قاضی همه وقت خیّام صفت سرگرم کشیدن و خوردن و نعره هَل مِن مَزید از جگر بر آوردن یضل الله مَن یشأ و یهدی من یهدی مَن یشأ
** (cont.) Nevertheless he as able to write history and poetry through the opium cloud (73): خلاصۀ عمر شریف را در ضمن کوکنار مصروف اشعار و تواریخ نموده

Khijlat (76b-77b) (this is the famous Bedil)
* Name (76b): میرزا عبد القادر بیدل
* No real info given, just poetry.

Kha'if (77b-78b) ابراهیم مخدوم اوره تپّه گی متخلص به خائف
* One of the nobles of Uratippa (77b): شخصی ست از اعیان بلدۀ مذکوره بزویر فضایل حمیده متخلص از علوم رسمی بهرۀ تمام یافته بلکه در هر فن از علوم بسیار کامل در صنعت شاعری و نظم گستری و او بلاغت و سخنوری داده
* (cont.) Ordered to Bukhara, where he stayed (77b): بعد از فترت ولایت اوره تپه حسب الفرمان حضرت ظل آلهی ببخارا آمده همراه متعلقان خود مشمول و ممنون عواطف بی غایت سلطانی گردیده 

Khatif (78b-79)
* Opening: خاطف از خوقند ست در سلک شعرأ محمد عمر خان حاکم آنجا منتظم بر اکثر کمالات واقف 
* Umar Khan favored him over others (78b): و خان مزبور را نسبت باو تلطف و تعطف از دیگران بیشتر بوده 
* Died in 1258

Khaqan (79-83)
* This is the bio of Fath Ali Khan Qajar; discussing him as a patron of the arts.
* Many poetical excerpts, some anecdotes (one involving Muhammad Ali Khan Khoqandi which I don't understand on p. 81)
 
Khalis (83-84)
